State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China Graphical abstract Controlling the oxygen-free product selectivity in catalytic hydrodeoxygenation is essential for producing high quality fuels from coal- and biomass-derived crude liquids. A series of boron-doped Ni/SiO2 catalysts were prepared for the efficient hydrodeoxygenation of dibenzofuran as a model compound. Boron doping significantly promoted the transformation of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol, which was accumulated as the main oxygen-containing intermediate compound on the pristine Ni/SiO2 catalyst, to the target products bicyclohexane and its isomer cyclopentylmethylcyclohexane. Characterization results show that boron doping increases Ni dispersion, modifies the electronic properties of Ni sites and in situ generates Brønsted acid sites by H2 spillover to boron oxides. The reduced Ni particle size improves the rates of dibenzofuran hydrogenation and 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol dehydration. Electron-deficient Ni and boron oxides as the Lewis acid sites enhance the adsorption of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol. Furthermore, the in situ generated Brønsted acid sites favor the dehydration of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol, which gives the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst a better deoxygenation activity than the mechanical mixture of equal amounts of 5B/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2, as well as the one with a smaller Ni particle size of 3.8 nm. Keywords Boron doping Ni particle size H2 dissociation Oxygen-containing intermediates Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. Nomenclature BAS Brønsted acid sites BCHs Bicyclohexane and its isomer cyclopentylmethylcyclohexane CHB Phenylcyclohexane CHCHE Cyclohexyl cyclohexene CHCHOH 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol CHCHO 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanone CHPOH 2-cyclohexylphenol DBF Dibenzofuran DFT Density functional theory DHDBF Dodecahydrodibenzofuran EXAFS Extended X-ray absorption fine structure HDO Hydrodeoxygenation HHDBF Hexahydrodibenzofuran LAS Lewis acid sites NH3-TPD Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia Py-FTIR FT infrared spectra of pyridine adsorption TEM Transmission electron microscopy TPD Temperature-programmed desorption TPR Temperature programmed reduction XAS X-ray absorption spectroscopy XANES X-ray absorption near edge structure XPS X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XRD X-ray diffraction patterns 1 Introduction Low-rank coal and biomass have attracted great interest as crucial sources for producing liquid fuels and chemicals [1,2]. However, the oxygen-rich property of fossilized and raw lignocellulose-derived oils reduces their quality, including poor chemical stability, low energy density and high viscosity [3,4]. Therefore, deoxygenation is essential to eliminate the above adverse properties as well as produce qualified fuels [5]. Oxygen removal from organic compounds can be achieved via hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). The catalytic cleaving of C−O bonds is identified as the crucial step, which determines the performance of the HDO process [6,7]. Among the various studies, Ni-based catalysts have received extensive research interests for their cost-effectiveness and high hydrotreatment activity for the HDO reaction [8–11]. However, it remains a great challenge to improve the selectivity of oxygen-free products due to the weak adsorption of the oxygen-containing intermediates, as reported in previous works [12–14]. Therefore, it is essential to strengthen the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates to improve the deoxygenation performance. In addition, H2 dissociation is considered a non-trivial factor influencing catalytic performance [15,16]. The heterolytically dissociated H2 prefers to hydrogenate C=O polar bonds, which are good acceptors for protons and hydrides [17]. Yang et al. investigated the effect of Ni particle size and found that the generation of highly coordination-unsaturated sites by reducing the Ni particle size improved the C−O cleavage ability via the facile adsorption and stabilization of –OH in the transition state [18]. Therefore, obtaining highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles is considered to be the key factor in enabling the excellent HDO performance. The introduction of a promoter is a highly efficient method to increase Ni dispersion. According to previous studies, Ni-Pt [19], Ni-Pd [20], and Ni-Cu [21] catalysts outperform the monometallic Ni catalyst, where high Ni metal dispersion is the crucial factor for better performance. In addition, the development of non-metallic promoters is essential to reduce catalyst costs, as recommended by Yan et al. [22]. Boron has shown promise as an effective catalyst promoter to increase the dispersion of active metal [23–25]. The introduction of boron oxide improved the dispersion and prevented the aggregation of Cu particles, which was mainly accountable for the outstanding performance of boron-doped Cu/SiO2 catalysts in glycerol hydrogenolysis reactions [26,27]. Furthermore, the effect of boron doping on catalyst stability has received more attention [28,29]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have shown that boron doping can increase the adsorption energies of the reaction intermediates on the Ni surface in the furfural HDO process [30]. Therefore, it can be speculated that boron can serve as a suitable promoter in enhancing HDO performance of Ni-based catalysts. However, the application of boron as a promoter in HDO reaction has been rarely investigated, and thus it is necessary to explore the applicability and mechanism of boron doping. In this context, a series of boron-doped Ni/SiO2 catalysts were prepared via the wet impregnation method and evaluated for the HDO performance with dibenzofuran (DBF) as a model oxygen-containing compound, because DBF is the least reactive molecule with a relatively high amount in crude oil from coal and biomass [31,32]. The effect of boron doping on the HDO performance of catalysts was revealed from Ni particle size, electronic structure and acid properties. DFT calculations were also employed to unveil the crucial role of boron doping in enhancing the adsorption of the oxygen-containing intermediates over the Ni-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ni-xB/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by sequential incipient wetness impregnation with solutions of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, Shanghai) and H3BO3 (Sinopharm Chemical ReagentCo., Ltd). A certain amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and commercial fumed SiO2 support (Aladdin, Shanghai) was added to deionized water to maintain a constant nominal metallic Ni loading of 5 wt% between different catalysts. After that, the mixed solution was dissolved by ultrasound for 30 min and was then stirred at room temperature until complete dryness. The obtained samples were subsequently dried at 90 °C for 12 h, calcined at 500 °C for 4 h and designated as Ni/SiO2. The collected Ni/SiO2 were added to different concentrations of aqueous H3BO3 solution and then stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The amounts of Ni and B precursors used are listed in Table S1 . The resulting samples were dried and calcined following the same procedure for obtaining Ni/SiO2. The boron doped samples were denoted as Ni-xB/SiO2, where x represents the theoretical mass percentage of doped boron. Finally, the obtained samples were reduced in H2 flow for 4 h at 500 °C and collected after cooling down. The Ni/SiO2+5B/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by mixing 5B/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2 mechanically in a mortar. The 5B/SiO2 preparation followed the procedure for the synthesis of the Ni-xB/SiO2 catalysts, except without the addition of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Ni/SiO2 catalysts with different Ni particle sizes were prepared with wetness impregnation and precipitation−deposition methods. First, 2.5 g of SiO2 was added to 100 mL of deionized water in a three-necked flask. Then, the Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and urea were added to the flask with different molar ratio of urea/Ni = 3:1 and 4:1, followed by sonication for 30 min. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 1 h and refluxed at 100 °C for 4 h. After that, the flask was opened and water were evaporated at 90 °C with stirring. The resulting samples were then calcined and reduced according to the same procedure used to synthesize the Ni-xB/SiO2 catalysts. These catalysts were denoted as Ni/SiO2-y, where y represents the Ni particle size. The amounts of Ni salt and urea used are listed in Table S1 . 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were acquired on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA, λ = 0.154 nm) over the 2θ range of 10°–80° at a rate of 3° min−1. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at the temperature of liquid N2 (77 K) using a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ3 instrument. Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed at 300 °C for 4 h under vacuum. The pore size distribution was obtained by the BJH model based on the adsorption branches of the isotherms. The surface areas of the catalyst were determined by applying the BET method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was obtained on a FEI Talos F200x instrument operated at 200 kV. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Kratos Analytical AXIS SUPRA (Shimadzu) equipped with a monochromatic radiation source Al-Kα. Prior to the test, the catalyst powders were pressed into a self-supporting wafer. Then, the sample was reduced in H2 at 500 °C for 4 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the sample was transferred in a glove box to the air-free transfer arm, which was then attached to the XPS instrument. The Fourier Transform Infrared spectra of pyridine adsorption (Py-FTIR) were collected to determine the amount of Brønsted acid sites (BAS) and Lewis acid sites (LAS) of catalysts on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer operating at a resolution of 4 cm−1 by collecting 64 scans for a single spectrum. For each measurement, the reduced catalyst samples (ca. 10 mg) were pressed to a self-supporting wafer with a diameter of 13 mm. This wafer was first treated at 400 °C under 10−1 Pa for 1 h in a quartz IR cell equipped with two CaF2 windows. When the wafer cooled down to 40 °C, the catalyst backbone spectrum was recorded. Then, the pyridine was introduced to the IR cell for 10 min until saturation at 40 °C. To evacuate the weakly adsorbed pyridine, the wafer was heated to 150 °C and held for 0.5 h under vacuum and the spectrum was then collected at when the sample was cooled to 40 °C. The adsorption of pyridine was performed to investigate the influence of boron doping on H2 dissociation on the same FTIR spectrometer. Prior to measurement, the reduced catalyst samples (ca. 10 mg) were first pressed to a self-supporting wafer with a diameter of 13 mm. This wafer was pretreated at 280 °C (selected according to the reaction temperature) for 1 h in flowing H2 (50 mL/min). After cooled down to 100 °C, evacuation was performed under 10−1 Pa for 1 h, and the catalyst backbone spectrum was recorded. The sample was heated to 100 °C and held for 0.5 h to collect the spectrum after the pyridine adsorption procedure described above. After that, H2 was introduced into the IR cell for 10 min and another spectrum was recorded. FT infrared spectra of carbon monoxide (CO-FTIR) were carried out on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer at a resolution of 4 cm−1 by collecting 64 scans for a single spectrum. For each measurement, all catalyst samples were pressed into a self-supporting wafer (ca. 10 mg) with a diameter of 13 mm. Prior to the measurements, the background was collected. Then, the sample was swept under a He flow for 0.5 h to clean up the cell and lines. After that, the wafer was reduced at 500 °C for 4 h in flowing 10 vol% H2/Ar gas. Then, the sample, was swept under a He flow for 1 h. After the wafer cooled down to 20 °C under He flow, the background spectrum of the catalyst backbone was recorded. The 5 vol% CO/He (40 mL min−1) was introduced into the sample cell at 20 °C for 0.5 h. Subsequently, the gas-phase and weakly adsorbed CO were removed by purging with He for 0.5 h, and after that the spectra were collected. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was performed using a Micrometrics Autochem II-2920 to determine the total acid amounts. For each measurement, the sample (ca. 50 mg) was first reduced in flowing H2 (50 mL/min) at 500 °C for 4 h. It was then purged with He for 1 h and then cooled to 100 °C. At this temperature, NH3 adsorption was performed in a flow of 3 vol% NH3/He (50 mL/min) for 1 h. After that, the sample was purged with He for another 1 h. Then the desorption profiles of NH3 were collected by heating the sample from 100 to 900 °C in flowing He at 50 mL/min. The total acid amount was calculated by injecting standard NH3 gas for calibration. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was performed on the same Micrometrics Autochem II-2920. Prior to measurements, the calcined catalyst was pretreated at 400 °C for 1 h in flowing Ar (50 mL min−1). After cooling to 50 °C, 25 mL/min of 10 % H2/Ar was introduced, and the sample was heated with the temperature increasing from 50 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Temperature-programmed desorption of H2 (H2-TPD) was carried out on the same Autochem II-2920. Prior to the H2-TPD test, the sample was first reduced in flowing H2 (50 mL/min) at 500 °C for 4 h. The sample was swept under He flow for 1 h and then cooled to 50 °C. At this temperature, H2 adsorption was performed in a flow of 10 vol% H2/Ar (50 mL/min) for 2 h, and after that, the sample was swept with He for another 1 h. Finally, the desorption profiles of H2 were recorded with the temperature increasing from 50 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The Ni dispersions were calculated according to Eq. (1) . (1) D Ni (%) = V ad W s × M Ni × SF F Ni × V m × 100 where Vad (mL) is the chemisorbed H2 volume derived from H2-TPD under standard temperature and pressure. Ws is the mass of the catalyst sample (g) and MNi is the molar mass of Ni (58.69 g/mol). SF is the stoichiometric factor (the H2/Ni molar ratio for chemisorption), which is defined as 2. FNi is the Ni mass percentage of the sample determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis and Vm is the molar volume of H2 (22414 mL/mol) under standard temperature and pressure. Temperature-programmed desorption was performed to determine the uptake amount of key oxygen-containing compounds in the catalysts on the same Autochem II-2920. 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol (CHCHOH) was substituted by cyclohexanol, which is more volatile and suitable for the pulse adsorption process. The catalyst was first reduced at 500 °C for 4 h in a flow of H2 (50 mL/min), followed by sweeping with He for 0.5 h. After cooling to 120 °C, cyclohexanol pulses were injected until the adsorption reached saturation. After this, the cell and lines were then purged with Ar gas for 2 h. Subsequently, the temperature was ramped to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and the signals were collected by a mass spectrometer (Hiden Analytical HPR-20 EGA). Ni K-edge X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) were performed on the BL14W1 beamline at the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF), Shanghai Institute of Applied Physics (SINAP), China, operated at 3.5 GeV. A Si (111) double-crystal monochromator was used to reduce the harmonic component of the monochrome beam. Ni foil and NiO were used as reference samples and measured in transmission mode. B K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra were recorded at the Catalysis and Surface Science End Station at the BL11U beamline in the National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (NSRL) in Hefei, China. 2.3 Catalytic measurements The catalyst activity was tested in a 200 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer (MS-25OH-316L-BS, Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd). For each test, the pre-reduced catalyst (60 mg) was dispersed in a mixed solution containing 96 wt% n-decane, 3 wt% DBF, and 1 wt% n-dodecane (the internal standard). Subsequently, N2 was introduced to purge the autoclave and gas lines for three times. Then, the pressure of N2 was raised to 0.1 MPa gauge pressure, and the reactor was heated to 280 °C with a stirring speed of 700 rpm. After that, H2 was introduced and raised to a gauge pressure of 6.0 MPa. The reaction was run for 180 min, and the products were collected every 10 min through a dip tube. HDO of CHCHOH was carried out over Ni/SiO2 and Ni-5B/SiO2 catalysts under H2 and N2 atmospheres and the evaluation conditions were the same as the HDO of DBF. The products were analyzed on a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Agilent 7890B/5977A) with an HP-5 column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). The injection volume was 1 μL, and the split ratio was 100:1. The column effluent is split into two halves with a post-column splitter followed by a MS and a FID detector, which were used together for qualitative and quantitative analysis. For quantification, we injected the standards of different products identified from the MS detector to gain their FID response factors relative to n-dodecane. The molar correction factors relative to the internal standard are calculated using Eq. (2). The amount of substance of products is calculated using Eq. (3). The DBF conversion, selectivity, and yield of different products are calculated according to Eqs. (4), (5) and (6), respectively. (2) f i = A i A s (3) n i = A i A s × f i × n s (4) X ( % ) = n 0 - n t n 0 × 100 (5) S ( % ) = n i n DBF × 100 (6) Y ( % ) = X × S where A i, and n i represent the areas of the peak and amounts of substance of the different products, respectively. The A s and n s represent the areas of the peak and the amounts of substance of the n-dodecane. The n0 and n t are the quantity of DBF (mol) detected at t = 0 and t, respectively. The nDBF represents the converted quantity of DBF (mol). The X, S, and Y represent the DBF conversion, the selectivity and yield of products, respectively. The absence of mass transport limitations was assessed by the Mears criterion for external diffusion and Weisz-Prater criterion for internal diffusion [33–35]. The calculated number under reaction conditions is 2.48 × 10−8 for the Mears criterion and 1.13 × 10−6 for the Weisz-Prater criterion. Therefore, internal and external mass transfer limitation could be neglected during the kinetic experiments. See Supplementary Material for details. Turnover frequencies (TOFs) were calculated from the conversion of DBF or CHCHOH per mole of active site per hour according to Eq. (7). The intrinsic rates and TOFs were calculated from the conversion values in a 10-min time window after the induction period. All conversions used for calculations were kept below 20 % by adjusting the amount of catalyst. (7) TOF = r × M Ni D Ni × F Ni where, r is the intrinsic conversion rates of DBF or CHCHOH ( mol g c a t - 1 h - 1 ). MNi represents the molar mass of Ni (58.69 g/mol). DNi is the dispersion of Ni. FNi is the Ni mass percentage determined by ICP-OES analysis. 2.4 Computational methods The surface model was established by a periodic 6 × 6 supercells. A four-layer slab was selected for the Ni(111) surface, and an eight-layer slab was used for the Ni(211) surface. The Ni(111)-B2O3 surface model was constructed by placing a B2O3 cluster on a Ni(111) slab. The edges of the boron oxide cluster were closed up with hydrogen atoms to simulate the in situ generation of hydroxyl groups and to eliminate the effects of unsaturated bonds at the edges. The adsorption configurations of CHCHOH on a Ni atom and a boron atom on the Ni(111)-B2O3 surface were denoted as Ni(111)-B2O3[Ni] and Ni(111)-B2O3[B], respectively. The bottom two or four layers were frozen, and the top layers together with the adsorbates were allowed to relax. A vacuum thickness of 15 Å was applied in the calculations. The DFT calculations were carried out by using Dmol3 code as implemented in the Materials Studio program package, in which a double numerical polarization (DNP) basis set was used. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof function (PBE) was applied, considering the exchange–correlation function. As Ni possesses the magnetic property, the spin-unrestricted method was adopted in this study. The DFT semi-core pseudopotential (DSSP) method was applied in the calculations to treat the core electrons. A Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid of 3 × 3 × 1 was sampled for the Brillouin zone integration. Adsorption energy E ads is defined as the Eq. (8). (8) E ads = E adsorbate/slab - E slab - E adsorbate where E adsorbate/slab is the total energy of the adsorbate and slab, E adsorbate represents the energy of gas-phase radical species, and E slab refers to the energy of the clean Ni(111), Ni(211) or Ni(111)-B2O3 surface. The activation energy (E act) and reaction energy (E rxn) are calculated as the Eqs. (9) and (10). (9) E act = E transition - E reactant (10) E rxn = E product - E reactant where E product, E reactant, and E transition represent the total energies of product, reactant, and transition state, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 a presents the XRD patterns of the reduced Ni-xB/SiO2 catalysts with different amounts of boron doping. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.4° are assigned to the (111), (200), and (220) planes, respectively, of face-centered cubic structured Ni (JCPDS 70-1849). Among them, only the Ni-5B/SiO2 and Ni-10B/SiO2 catalysts present distinguished characteristic peaks at 14.6° and 27.8° corresponding to B2O3 (JCPDS 06–0297), indicating that the excess boron formed crystalline particles on the surface of the SiO2 support. Consistent results are observed in the N2 adsorption–desorption of the Ni-5B/SiO2 and Ni-10B/SiO2 catalysts, in which the decline in BET surface area is more significant compared to the Ni-0.5B/SiO2 and Ni-1B/SiO2 catalysts (Table 1 and Fig. S1 ). Besides, all catalysts exhibit a broad diffraction peak at ca. 21.7°, which is the characteristic peak of amorphous SiO2 [36]. The relative intensity of Ni characteristic peaks diminishes and these peaks broaden as a result of boron doping, indicating that boron doping has an effect on the active metal Ni. The average particle size of Ni metal, calculated using the Scherer equation, decreases from 11.4 nm for the pristine Ni/SiO2 catalyst to 5.0 nm for the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst (Table 1). These results suggest that boron doping alleviates the migration and agglomeration of Ni to form larger particle sizes during the reduction process, since the interaction between Ni metal and boron species is stronger than that of SiO2 [26]. However, the Ni particle size displays an increase when further increasing the boron doping amounts (Ni-10B/SiO2). This phenomenon may be due to the excess of boron doping leading to an excessive replacement of the interaction between the Ni metal and SiO2 by that between the Ni metal and boron oxides. The migration of Ni particles is accelerated in the low melting point boron oxides, causing the Ni particles to grow into larger ones [27]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the above catalysts provide further insight into the effect of boron doping on the Ni size distribution. As shown in Fig. 1 b–f, the Ni metal particles present better dispersion in the catalyst when the amount of boron doping was not higher than 5 wt%. For the Ni-10B/SiO2 catalyst, an obvious aggregation of Ni species is observed. The corresponding average particle size distributions fitted by the Gaussian function are 11.6 ± 0.3, 9.2 ± 0.2, 8.6 ± 0.2, 4.6 ± 0.4, and 11.0 ± 0.4 nm for the Ni/SiO2, Ni-0.5B/SiO2, Ni-1B/SiO2, Ni-5B/SiO2, and Ni-10B/SiO2 catalysts, respectively, as shown in Table 1. This trend is in agreement with that of the XRD results. The influence of boron doping on the reducibility of the catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR and the results are shown in Fig. 2 a. The Ni/SiO2 catalyst displays two reduction peaks centered at 322 and 460 °C, which arise from the sequential partial and complete reduction of NiO to metallic Ni [37]. The boron-doped catalysts display a higher reduction temperature compared to the pristine Ni/SiO2 catalyst and the reduction temperature increased with increasing boron doping amounts, whereas the reduction temperature of Ni-10B/SiO2 decreases. The increase in reduction temperature is considered to be associated with a stronger interaction between the basic nickel oxide and the acidic boric oxide than that of SiO2 [26]. The decrease in the reduction temperature of the Ni-10B/SiO2 catalyst may be due to the decrease in its Ni dispersion, in agreement with the previous study that larger NiO crystallites interact more weakly with the support, presenting a lower reduction temperature [20,35]. In addition, the molar ratio of H2 consumption to Ni (H2/Ni) was quantified in the H2-TPR. As shown in Table S2 , the H2/Ni molar ratio of the pristine Ni/SiO2 is 0.99, indicating that the NiO is almost completely reduced. However, the H2/Ni molar ratios of Ni-1B/SiO2 and Ni-5B/SiO2 catalysts are 1.03 and 1.12. For comparison, the H2-TPR measurement of 5B/SiO2 without Ni loading was performed and no H2 consumption peaks was observed. Therefore, it can be speculated that the excess H2 consumption is the result of Ni promoting the partial reduction of boron oxides. H2-TPD experiments were performed to examine the surface-active sites. Fig. 2 b presents the H2-desorption profiles of the Ni-xB/SiO2 catalysts and the quantitative results are shown in Table 1. The H2-desorption amounts increased for the boron-doped catalyst compared to the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, in which the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst possesses the highest amount of H2-desorption at two times that of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst. This result indicates that more Ni surface sites are exposed due to boron doping. The Ni dispersion calculated on the basis of H2 desorption amount shows a similar trend to the XRD and TEM results, demonstrating that boron doping exhibits the authority to control the growth of Ni particle size during the reduction process. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts The HDO mechanism of DBF on the Ni (111) surface was investigated in our previous work [13] and the proposed reaction network is shown in Scheme S1. The aromatic rings of DBF can be firstly hydrogenated to form hexahydrodibenzofuran (HHDBF). HHDBF is a common intermediate in two parallel routes: one involving C−O bond scission (formation of 2-cyclohexylphenol (CHPOH)), which leads to the formation of cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) and 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanone (CHCHO), and the other involving ring hydrogenation (dodecahydrodibenzofuran (DHDBF) formation) leading to CHCHOH formation. The target products bicyclohexane and its isomer cyclopentylmethylcyclohexane (calculated together as BCHs) can be obtained by the hydrogenation of CHB or the sequential dehydration of CHCHOH and hydrogenation of cyclohexylcyclohexene (CHCHE). Thus, we divided the reaction scheme into 3 routes: route A ). The DBF conversion over Ni-xB/SiO2 catalysts as a function of reaction time is compared in Fig. S2 . To reach complete conversion, 120, 70, 70, 60, and 110 min were needed for the Ni/SiO2, Ni-0.5B/SiO2, Ni-1B/SiO2, Ni-5B/SiO2 and Ni-10B/SiO2 catalysts, respectively. These results indicated that the boron-doped catalysts displayed higher hydrogenation activity compared to the Ni/SiO2 catalyst. To investigate the effect of boron doping on the performance of different catalysts, the intrinsic rates and TOFs were given in Fig. 3 a. It can be observed that with increasing boron doping amounts, the intrinsic rates increase from 153.9 mmol h−1gcat −1 on Ni/SiO2 to 364.7 mmol h−1gcat −1 on Ni-5B/SiO2. However, a further increase in the amounts of boron doping from 5 % to 10 % results in a decrease in DBF conversion rate. However, the TOFs of Ni-xB/SiO2 catalysts were almost unchanged with the amount of boron doping. That is, the boron doping raises the amounts of active sites but does not alter the activity of each site for the hydrogenation of DBF. The selectivity variations of the main oxygen-containing intermediate and target products with reaction time are shown in Fig. 3 b and c. As shown in Fig. 3 b, the selectivity of CHCHOH first increases and then decreases with prolonged reaction time for all the catalysts. For the pristine Ni/SiO2 catalyst, the CHCHOH selectivity reaches a maximum of 51.7 % at 150 min and then decreases to 44.1 % at 180 min. Consistent with our previous findings [13], the dehydration of CHCHOH during DBF hydrodeoxygenation is considered a challenge due to its weak adsorption on pure Ni metal. Comparatively, the selectivity of CHCHOH reaches the peak at 30 min and it can not even be detected at 150 min for the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst. Meanwhile, the BCHs selectivity of the boron-doped catalysts improves distinctly with prolonged reaction time and reaches up to 99.4 % for the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst at 180 min. However, the selectivity of BCHs is only 39.9 % for Ni/SiO2 at 180 min (Fig. 3 c). In addition, to better understand the role of boron doping in the reaction, the yields of CHCHOH and BCHs on different catalysts at a similar DBF conversion based on the above catalyst evaluation results are shown in Fig. S3 . It can be observed that the yields of CHCHOH decrease monotonously with increasing boron doping. However, the yields of BCHs increase with increasing boron doping amounts up to 5 % and then decrease when the boron doping reaches 10 %. These results illustrate that boron doping obviously improves the CHCHOH dehydration activity of Ni/SiO2 catalysts. As CHCHOH was the major oxygen-containing intermediate compound on the pristine Ni/SiO2, its conversion can be used to directly measure the deoxygenation activity of catalysts by eliminating the influence of the hydrogenation reaction for compounds with aromatic rings. Thus, the deoxygenation activity of the Ni-xB/SiO2 catalysts was evaluated using the intrinsic rates and TOFs based on the CHCHOH conversion and the results are shown in Fig. 3 d. It is found that the intrinsic rates and TOFs of Ni-xB/SiO2 first increase with increasing boron doping amounts up to 5 % and then decreases when the boron doping reaches 10 %. The TOFs increase 1.97 times from 688.5 h−1 on Ni/SiO2 to 1354.6 h−1 on Ni-5B/SiO2. These results indicate that a suitable boron doping amount increases the deoxygenation activity of each active site. The reaction kinetics were also analyzed and more details of the fitting model are described in the Supplementary Material . The calculated concentration obtained by fitting are shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. S4 as continuous solid lines with the corresponding experimental values as scattered data points. The reaction rate constants obtained from the fitting are presented in Table S3 . It can be noted that, compared to Ni/SiO2, Ni-5B/SiO2 presents higher rate constant for each step of the reaction network (Scheme S1) proposed in our previous work [13]. Among them, the ring-opening rates of HHDBF and DHDBF are significantly improved for the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst (k 4 and k 6), compared to Ni/SiO2. Consistent with the results of our previous DFT study [13], CHCHOH dehydration over the pristine Ni/SiO2 catalyst is the rate-determining step with the smallest reaction rate constant (k 9) of only 0.17 h−1 among all reaction steps in routes B and C. Boron doping increased the dehydration activity of CHCHOH significantly, with the rate constant increasing to 2.42 h−1 for Ni-5B/SiO2. 3.3 Effects of boron doping on the catalytic behavior of catalysts To clarify the role of boron doping on the rate-determining step (CHCHOH dehydration) of routes B and C, CHCHOH was selected as the reactant for further investigation. As shown in Fig. 5 a and b, a faster CHCHOH conversion and a higher BCHs selectivity are obtained for the boron-doped catalysts than that of the pristine Ni/SiO2. A closer examination of the main intermediates reveals that the selectivity of CHCHE over the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst is higher than others, reaching a maximum of 77.7 % after 10 min (Fig. 5 c). In addition, the yields of CHCHE on different catalysts at a similar CHCHOH conversion level based on the catalyst evaluation results (Fig. 5 a and c) are drawn in Fig. S5 . It can be observed that the yield of CHCHE on the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst is higher than that on Ni/SiO2 for a similar CHCHOH conversion. These results show that the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst possesses a higher dehydration activity than the pristine Ni/SiO2 catalyst. Considering that CHCHE selectivity over different catalysts is influenced by its further hydrogenation to BCHs, the deoxygenation activity of boron-doped catalysts was evaluated under N2. The catalytic performance of 5B/SiO2 on CHCHOH conversion was studied as a control to clarify whether boron can catalyze alone or have to cooperate with Ni metal in deoxygenation. As shown in Fig. 5 d, the CHCHOH conversion values of Ni-1B/SiO2 and Ni-5B/SiO2 catalysts are higher than those of Ni/SiO2 and 5B/SiO2 catalysts, suggesting that Ni and boron exhibit a synergistic effect. In the case of product distribution, as shown in Fig. 5 e, CHCHE is observed for all the catalysts, indicating that dehydration can occur in the presence of boron or Ni alone. However, the yield of CHCHE first increases and then decreases for the boron-doped catalysts, while it increases monotonously for the Ni/SiO2 and 5B/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 5 e). Correspondingly, the dehydrogenation product CHB and hydrogenation saturation product BCHs were only detected on the boron-doped catalysts (Fig. 5 f). This indicates that, in the absence of external hydrogen supply, intermolecular hydrogen transfer can occur over boron-doped catalysts. CHCHE can be converted via two pathways: intermolecular hydrogen transfer and direct dehydrogenation. In the intermolecular hydrogen transfer pathway, CHCHE molecules act as both the hydrogen donors and acceptors to form CHB and BCHs. The yield of BCHs should be twice that of CHB if only intermolecular hydrogen transfer occurs. However, the yield of CHB is higher than that of BCHs as shown in Fig. 5 f. This means that direct dehydrogenation is the dominant pathway under the N2 atmosphere, leading to the production of CHB and H2 gas [38]. A closer examination of the dehydrogenation products shows that CHCHO was detected on the Ni/SiO2, Ni-1B/SiO2 and Ni-5B/SiO2 catalysts, while it was not detected for the 5B/SiO2 catalyst. It suggests that the Ni metal is essential for the abstraction and intermolecular transfer of hydrogen. As discussed above, boron doping promotes the yield of BCHs by improving the dehydration activity of Ni/SiO2 catalysts for CHCHOH. We initially inferred that the reasons for the excellent deoxygenation activity may be two-fold: First, boron oxides serve as LAS ( Fig. S6 ) that enhance the adsorption of CHCHOH and functions together with Ni metal. Second, more active sites are exposed owing to the decreased Ni particle sizes by boron doping. However, the change in Ni particle size is accompanied by alterations in the acid properties with the introduction of boron. Therefore, the effect of boron-related acid sites and the particle size alterations on catalytic performance cannot be distinguished. To unveil the specific role of the two aspects, the role of particle size on the deoxygenation activity was investigated using three Ni/SiO2 catalysts with different Ni particle sizes (3.8, 8.0 and 11.6 nm) as shown in Fig. S7 and S8 . The Ni/SiO2 catalyst with a Ni particle size of 11.6 nm is the same as that used in the section 3.2. The Ni/SiO2-3.8 and Ni/SiO2-8.0 are prepared with a precipitation−deposition method. In addition, mechanical mixture of equal amounts of 5B/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2 was also employed for comparison. 3.3.1 Effects of Ni particle size and boron acid sites The effects of Ni particle sizes and acid properties on the performance of Ni/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 a–c. It can be seen that the DBF conversion and BCHs selectivity showed positive trends with decreasing Ni particle sizes. However, the acid site introduction by mechanical mixing with 5B/SiO2 exhibits no facilitating effect on the DBF conversion and only slightly increases the selectivity of BCHs. However, a comparison between Ni/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2+5B/SiO2 for the CHCHOH selectivity shows that the 5B/SiO2 introduction promotes the conversion of CHCHOH (Fig. 6 c). The main oxygen-containing intermediate CHCHOH was employed to probe the role of particle size and acid sites in enhancing the deoxygenation activity of Ni/SiO2 catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. S9 . It is obvious that the decrease in Ni particle size facilitates the CHCHOH conversion and improves the yield of BCHs. In comparison, the introduction of 5B/SiO2 only slightly improves the CHCHOH conversion and BCHs yield. These results demonstrate that the effect of acid site by mechanical mixing introduction on the improvement of dehydration activity is not significant. Moreover, the TOFs for CHCHOH conversion increases from 688.5 to 1140.5 h−1 when Ni particle size decreases from 11.6 to 3.8 nm, which indicates that the surface Ni atoms on smaller particles with more step and corner sites favor CHCHOH dehydration. This is further proved by DFT calculations in Section 3.4. Notably, as shown in Fig. 6 a-c, Ni-5B/SiO2 exhibits close performance of DBF HDO to that of Ni/SiO2-3.8 catalyst, although the former possesses a larger Ni particle size (i.e. 4.6 nm). In addition, the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst displays a higher dehydration activity (Fig. 5 c and Fig. S9 b), with 77.7 % CHCHE being detected after 10 min reaction, while a negligible amount of CHCHE was observed on the Ni/SiO2-3.8 catalyst under the H2 atmosphere. The CHCHE yields on different catalysts at a similar CHCHOH conversion based on the catalyst evaluation results (Fig. 5 a and c, Fig. S9a and b ) are drawn as shown in Fig. S5 . The Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst presents a significantly higher CHCHE yield than the Ni/SiO2-3.8 catalyst, suggesting that the enhanced dehydration activity by boron doping is not due to particle size reduction. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 5 a and d, for the same Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst, CHCHOH was converted faster in H2 than in N2. Correspondingly, the dehydration product CHCHE was produced faster in H2 than in N2. However, this phenomenon was not observed for the pristine Ni/SiO2. This means that the dehydration activity of Ni-5B/SiO2 was affected by the reaction atmosphere, which may change the local microenvironment on the catalyst in situ. These results confirm that, besides the acid sites managed by boron oxides and the reduction in Ni particle size, other effects induced by boron doping gave the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst its excellent dehydration activity. 3.3.2 Electronic properties and BAS generation To gain deeper insights into the effect of boron doping on the catalytic mechanism, the local geometry of Ni and B in Ni-1B/SiO2 and Ni-5B/SiO2 were investigated by XAS. As shown in Fig. S10 , it can be observed that the position and shape of the peaks in the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra of the boron-doped catalysts are quite similar to those of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst. The peak corresponding to the Ni-B bonds cannot be distinguished, in line with previous reports, which may be due to the weak interaction between the electrons from the Ni excited by X-rays and B atoms [39]. The B K-edge was also studied by the XANES and the results are shown in Fig. S11 . The sharp peak at 194 eV and the broad peak at 197–199 eV are assigned to the edge feature of the trigonal and tetrahedral B, respectively. The broad peak at 200–205 eV is attributed to the conjunction of the trigonal and tetrahedral B. Among them, the peak at 200–201 eV is assigned to the tetrahedral B, and 203–204 eV is attributed to the trigonal B [40,41]. The sharp peak in the spectrum of the boron-doped catalysts closely resembles that of the B2O3 reference and Its intensity decreases as the amount of boron doping decreases, indicating that the boron species exists mainly in the form of boron oxides. In addition, it can be noted that the peak at 200–205 eV shifts toward the tetrahedral B (203–204 eV). This phenomenon can be explained by the reduction of tetrahedral B attached to Ni species. However, these results do not reveal the presence of Ni−B bonds in combination with the Ni-edge analysis. Considering that XAS is a bulk technique, it is difficult to detect the alloy species that are only formed on the particle surface, as observed on Ni–W by Yang et al [10,42]. Moreover, according to previous reports, the doped boron preferentially occupies the surface and subsurface of Ni [30]. As a consequence, XPS and in situ CO adsorption FTIR, as more sensitive surface techniques, were performed to examine the changes on the surface. XPS analysis was employed to investigate the chemical state of the reduced catalysts. As shown in the Ni 2p spectrum (Fig. 7 a), the peak at 852.7 eV is assigned to Ni0 and a positive shift was observed for the boron-doped catalysts compared to Ni/SiO2, suggesting that the active metal site of Ni was in an electron deficient state. In Fig. 7 b, the strong B 1 s peak centered at 193.8 eV is attributed to B3+, indicating that the introduced boron species exist mostly in the form of boron oxides, in agreement with the XAS results and previous reports [28,43]. In addition, a weak peak at ca. 191.7 eV is observed and attributed to the partial reduction of boron oxides to B0 and the binding energy of the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst displayed a negative shift compared to Ni-1B/SiO2 [28,44]. This phenomenon indicates that electrons transfer from Ni to B or boron oxides due to their electron scavenging property [26,27]. These results were also confirmed by the Bader charge analysis in Section 3.4 for the NiB (111) and Ni(111)-B2O3, which showed 0.19 and 1.16 e transfer from Ni to B0 or boron oxides cluster, respectively. Considering that boron oxides may also be reduced by gas-phase H2 directly or by the spillover H2 activated by the physically separated Ni, XPS was carried out on the 5B/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2+5B/SiO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. S12 , the partial reduction of boron oxides was not detected. It can therefore be speculated that H2 is activated by Ni and spills over to the nearby boron species, resulting in the formation of Ni-B alloy [29]. The effects of boron doping on the chemical properties and surface state of Ni were further investigated by in situ CO adsorption FTIR. As shown in Fig. S13a , the bands at 2055 and 1927 cm−1 of Ni/SiO2 are attributed to the linear and bridge-type adsorption on the Ni metal, respectively [45]. For the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalysts, a blue shift of the linear and bridge-type adsorption could be observed compared to that of Ni/SiO2. Considering the boron doping also led to a decrease in Ni particle sizes, the in situ CO adsorption FTIR were performed on the Ni/SiO2 catalysts with different Ni particle sizes as well (Ni/SiO2, and Ni/SiO2-3.8) and the results are shown in Fig. S13b . Compared to the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, a red shift of the linear and bridge-type adsorption could be observed as the Ni particle size decreased from 11.6 to 3.8 nm. As a result of the decrease in Ni particle size, higher amount of corner and edge atoms are generated which are more coordinatively unsaturated, which leads to a greater degree of electron back-donation into the anti-bonding π* orbital of CO [46]. This confirms that the blue shift is caused by the transfer of electrons from the Ni atoms to the B atoms. This conclusion coincides with the XPS results that boron doping modifies the electronic properties of Ni metal. The above results indicate that the doped boron is present in the form of a large amount of boron oxides and a tiny amount of Ni-B alloy. The catalyst evaluation results demonstrate that boron doping enhances the CHCHOH dehydration, which is regarded as the rate-determining step of routes B and C, and thus elevates the HDO performance of Ni-based catalysts. Therefore, the uptake of cyclohexanol was compared on different catalysts, based on the amount of cyclohexanol chemisorption determined by cyclohexanol-TPD. The results are shown in Fig. 8 a and the intensity of the cyclohexanol desorption signal of Ni/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2-3.8 is enlarged by 10-fold for better comparison. Compared to Ni/SiO2, the amount of cyclohexanol uptake on the Ni/SiO2-3.8 catalyst presents a slight increase. Compared to Ni/SiO2, the amount of cyclohexanol uptake on the Ni/SiO2-3.8 catalyst presents a slight increase. However, the amount of cyclohexanol desorption on Ni-5B/SiO2 exhibits a much more significant increase, although its Ni particle size is larger than that of Ni/SiO2-3.8. In addition, the boron doping makes the dominant cyclohexanol desorption peak centered at 252 °C for the Ni/SiO2 catalyst move to higher temperature than that of Ni/SiO2-3.8, suggesting that the chemisorption strength is enhanced. These results indicate that the effect of boron doping on the promotion of CHCHOH adsorption is more significant than the decrease of Ni particle size. Besides the enhancement of CHCHOH adsorption, H2 can also spill over to the adjacent boron oxides, where we infer that H3BO3-like structures may be generated. Therefore, the effect of boron doping on the H2 dissociation was investigated by in situ pyridine FTIR. As shown in Fig. 8 b, the spectrum of pyridine adsorbed on the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst gives rise to bands at 1628 and 1610 cm−1, which are attributed to the coordinatively bonded pyridine at LAS [47,48]. The band at 1546 cm−1 is assigned to the proton acid site bonded to pyridine [49]. The intensity of 1546 cm−1 band increased, while all the characteristic bands of LAS (1628 and 1610 cm−1) reduced upon exposing the pyridine-saturated catalyst to H2. This means that the H+ species were obtained in situ as BAS via H2 spillover on Ni-5B/SiO2, which in turn promoted pyridine protonation. It was further confirmed by the emergence of a new band of promoted pyridine at 1640 cm−1 [47]. For comparison, Ni/SiO2, Ni/SiO2-3.8 and 5B/SiO2 catalysts were also selected and investigated using the same method as shown in Fig. 8 c-d and Fig. S14 . The increase in the bands at 1640 and 1546 cm−1 was not observed for these catalysts, indicating that the H2 dissociation differs from that of Ni-5B/SiO2. It can be concluded that the in situ generation of BAS by dissociation of H2 is a result of the formation of the Ni-B alloy or the H2 spillover to the boron oxides upon dissociation on Ni to form hydroxyl groups, rather than the change in Ni particle size or the presence of boron oxides alone. Moreover, the BAS could enhance dehydration reaction [50] and display a higher activity for the dehydration step compared to the LAS [12,51]. Therefore, the activity of the dehydration step can be significantly enhanced by the BAS generated in situ by H2 dissociation. This explains the improved CHCHOH conversion rate under H2, compared to than under N2, as well as the superior HDO performance of Ni-5B/SiO2. 3.4 DFT study on the adsorption and deoxygenation of CHCHOH The above results clearly demonstrate that the decrease of Ni particle size promotes the deoxygenation of CHCHOH originating from boron doping. To validate the findings from a theoretical perspective, the Ni(111) and Ni(211) surfaces were constructed to represent terrace sites rich on large particles and step sites rich on small particles, respectively. The most stable configurations for the adsorbates and the transition states, and the detailed Adsorption Energy (E ads), Reaction Energy (E rxn) and the Activation Energy (E act) are given in Fig. S15 . The adsorption energy of CHCHOH on Ni(111) is − 1.14 eV, which is lower than that of −1.24 eV on Ni(211). Furthermore, the CHCHOH activation was investigated on Ni(111) and Ni(211), where the barrier for dehydroxylation of CHCHOH on Ni(211) is decreased to 1.54 eV compared to that of 1.63 eV on Ni(111). The results indicate that the much more exposed step sites enhance the adsorption of CHCHOH and boost the activation of C−O bond as a result of the decrease of Ni particle size. Besides the particle size effect, experimental results demonstrated that boron doping also exhibits other effects to the dehydration of CHCHOH. Thus, DFT calculations were also performed on NiB(111) and Ni(111)-B2O3 to clarify the effects of boron doping on the adsorption and dehydration of CHCHOH. For Ni(111)-B2O3, two scenarios of CHCHOH adsorption were considered: on a Ni atom or on a boron atom of the B2O3 cluster. Despite the existence forms of boron, the adsorption energies of CHCHOH on the Ni(111)-B2O3 and NiB(111) are all larger than that on Ni(111), which is in good agreement with the experimental results obtained from the cyclohexanol-TPD. This is ascribed to the presence of B2O3 as the LAS and electron-deficient Ni, both of which are oxyphilic sites. Since boron and boron oxides have a greater electron affinity than SiO2, electrons transfer from Ni to boron or boron oxides, which is consistent with the results of XPS, CO-FTIR and Bader charge analysis. This stronger metal-adsorbate interaction boosts the dehydroxylation of CHCHOH. As shown in Fig. 9 , the activation barrier for the dehydroxylation of CHCHOH is 1.63 eV on Ni(111). Comparatively, this value is reduced to 1.29 eV, 1.53 eV and 1.22 eV on NiB(111), Ni(111)-B2O3[Ni] and Ni(111)-B2O3[B], respectively. Therefore, the C−O bond can be cleaved more readily on the boron-doped catalysts, which explains the better HDO performance of Ni-5B/SiO2 compared to Ni/SiO2 theoretically. 4 Conclusion Undoped Ni/SiO2 catalyst exhibits poor C–O bond dissociation ability in dibenzofuran hydrodeoxygenation, limiting the selectivity of oxygen-free products. Boron doping was found to be a promising method to improve the hydrodeoxygenation performance of Ni/SiO2 catalysts mainly by accelerating the dehydration of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol, which was the main accumulated oxygen-containing intermediate compound over the pristine Ni/SiO2 catalyst. Detailed characterization and DFT calculations revealed that the effects of boron doping are threefold: Ni dispersion increase, modification of the electronic properties Ni and in situ generation of Brønsted acid sites by H2 spillover. The reduction in Ni particle size enhances both dibenzofuran hydrogenation and 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol dehydration, as more exposed step and corner sites on smaller Ni particles can promote the adsorption of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol and boost the activation of C−O bonds. In addition, boron doping reduces the electron density of Ni. Boron oxides themselves and their induced electron-deficient Ni are both conducive to the adsorption of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol. Meanwhile, Ni–B alloy formation and hydrogen spillover to the boron oxides to form hydroxyl groups upon dissociation on Ni enables Brønsted acid sites to be generated in situ, thereby improving the dehydration rate of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol. This study indicates that boron doping is an effective modification approach for Ni-based catalysts to promote their hydrodeoxygenation performance. coredata.dc:description: Controlling the oxygen-free product selectivity in catalytic hydrodeoxygenation is essential for producing high quality fuels from coal- and biomass-derived crude liquids. A series of boron-doped Ni/SiO2 catalysts were prepared for the efficient hydrodeoxygenation of dibenzofuran as a model compound. Boron doping significantly promoted the transformation of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol, which was accumulated as the main oxygen-containing intermediate compound on the pristine Ni/SiO2 catalyst, to the target products bicyclohexane and its isomer cyclopentylmethylcyclohexane. Characterization results show that boron doping increases Ni dispersion, modifies the electronic properties of Ni sites and in situ generates Brønsted acid sites by H2 spillover to boron oxides. The reduced Ni particle size improves the rates of dibenzofuran hydrogenation and 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol dehydration. Electron-deficient Ni and boron oxides as the Lewis acid sites enhance the adsorption of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol. Furthermore, the in situ generated Brønsted acid sites favor the dehydration of 2-cyclohexylcyclohexanol, which gives the Ni-5B/SiO2 catalyst a better deoxygenation activity than the mechanical mixture of equal amounts of 5B/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2, as well as the one with a smaller Ni particle size of 3.8 nm.
